1_1B5iBCuHQgbGdgTJmM2A2pZNVfpfp3EU5u.body:
you can use hugo and probably even hexo, since these output static files. 

For hugo, just have to copy the "public/" folder to the zeronet folder that corresponds to your zero site
For hexo, just deploy via rsync to the zeronet folder that corresponds to your zero site

IDK how to do it with jekyllrb but I am sure as heck there is a way, you just need to copy the files it outputs to your zeronet site folder.

Hugo example
http://127.0.0.1:43110/126fBtopb2n7Pc42KhZyZyHhZKrecAdMdR/

> [sorcererr](#comment_2_183CohB4d2oHT8aEq41e8UbrdJu1SdNkHh): Thought: should we be worried about spammers harvesting these addresses and mass-mailing people? I mean that's not an issue yet, but it's almost guaranteed to become one in the future.

The only spamming they can do is DDOS IPs but there isn't much a stranger can do other than that from an retroshare certificate. 

Since it is a friend to friend network, no damage happens until someone breaks the chain of trust. However even then you can block out annoying people.
